the men were arrested when officers responded to what they assumed would be routine noise complaint police arrived at toolson lane the home of william provost at approximately pm on sunday evening in response to neighbor complaining of strange sounds coming from the home responding officers told reporters that they assumed their visit to the house would be quick one and that they would simply be asking the residents to keep the noise down when the officers arrived at toolson lane they repeatedly knocked on the door and rang the doorbell however nothing could be heard over the sound stereo inside the house repeatedly playing the same song which was later identified as enya who can say after attempting to get the attention of the homeowner via knocking and ringing the doorbell for approximately minutes police entered the home through an unlocked door located at the rear of the house the responding officers told reporters that the house had been extremely dark cluttered and an overwhelming smell which was later identified as decomposing flesh filled the home upon clearing the first floor of the home the responding officers realized that the blaring music was coming from the home basement according to the officers bizarre crime scene was quickly uncovered upon entering the basement three men which have since been identified as year old william provost year old dennis ratcliff and year old michael dore were sitting in circle on the basement concrete floor and ritualistically chanting while eating what police initially believed was an animal carcass but was later identified as human remains william provost who police believe to be the group ringleader admitted to practicing cannibalism and told arresting officers find human flesh to be the only thing that cures my type diabetes and chronic depression if expensive pharmaceutical drugs helped would figure out way to obtain them but they don so stick to what works for me upon searching the home basement police made several startling discoveries including large room that appears to contain nothing more than decades worth of clutter but upon further inspection police discovered human remains hidden throughout the old wooden furniture and broken appliances police also discovered kitchen style refrigerator located in small room in the corner of the basement that contained the limbs organs and miscellaneous remains of what police believe to be upwards of different individuals in addition to the refrigerator the small room in the basement also housed make shift tool wall that contained myriad of tools that police believe were used to dismember several victims upon their initial investigation police believe the men have been practicing cannibalism for the past years and largely remained under the radar due to their practice of targeting and befriending homeless drifters they met at small dive bars located upwards of miles from their vernal heights residence vernal heights chief of police gregory moore spoke to reporters during brief press conference this morning though modern day cannibalism is extremely rare it does unfortunately exist that said treating diabetes and or depression has to be the most bizarre reason for practicing cannibalism that ve ever heard provost accomplices year old dennis ratcliff and year old michael dore also admitted to cannibalizing human flesh because they believed it would cure depression and told arresting officer that provost took them under his wing in late as of tuesday afternoon police and detectives are still conducting search at the residence located at toolson lane all three men are currently being held without bail at the vernal heights municipal jail

nine years ago driver lost control of his pickup truck and crashed into the confederate monument on the front lawn of the franklin county courthouse decapitating the marble soldier some locals who found the monument offensive said they were glad to see it go but there was never much doubt that once the money was raised the soldier would be back the rededication ceremony in drew crowd of about people women wore hoop skirts and men donned the gray uniforms of confederate soldiers we re very proud of it says linda stanley managing director of the franklin county historical society in rocky mount virginia miles southeast of roanoke this whole county very very patriotic story continued below this was the way skirmishes over confederate history have often gone history is replaced not rewritten that is until last year when white supremacist dylann roof gunned down nine people at an african american church in charleston south carolina the massacre set off national debate about confederate symbols in public places leading to an intense and ultimately successful campaign to permanently remove the confederate flag from the south carolina capitol grounds where it had flown for decades but for every nationally publicized debate like the one over south carolina flag there are dozens of smaller battles in places like franklin county and this is especially true in virginia which as the former home to the capital of the confederacy has more confederate monuments than any other state virginia increasingly diverse and progressive embodies the friction between the economic aspirations of the new south and the still powerful nostalgia of the old dominion and it drama that is playing out in town squares across the state though quinnipiac university poll last summer found virginians evenly divided on the governor decision to remove the confederate flag from state license plates pride in local monuments remains strong when city leaders in danville on virginia southern border voted to remove confederate flag from the grounds of the sutherlin mansion known as the last capitol of the confederacy confederate struck back they filed lawsuit seeking to have the flag reinstated arguing that it was part of war memorial and that virginia law protected all war memorials in the state last fall circuit court judge ruled against them that ruling along with the increasingly frequent threats to monuments around the state prompted the republican delegate from franklin county to demand in january blanket protection for what has been feature of southern urban landscapes for more than century charles poindexter introduced bill in the general assembly to prevent the removal of all war monuments regardless of when they were built if you eliminate these monuments and memorials you re taking away the opportunity to learn the history of the country to learn the good the bad and ugly poindexter says many of his colleagues in the virginia legislature agreed with him but in march democratic governor terry mcauliffe vetoed the bill saying cities and towns should decide what to do with their confederate monuments based on their individual histories some historians and civic leaders think the debate over confederate symbols in public spaces which began in the will take decades to play out every little statue part of much larger discussion and movement says edward ayers former president of the university of richmond and noted civil war historian african americans now have political voice and this is one of the things that they re using it for mark whitaker remembers walking by the foot tall confederate monument in portsmouth virginia when he was kid shopping at store across the street he resented looking at the obelisk guarded by stone soldiers his parents had told him what it represented my ancestors could not say thing in the face of that indignity whitaker says now as an african american city council member in city that is percent black he wants to remove the monument from the center of olde towne and perhaps put it in cemetery these monuments are really rally and celebration of the rise of an institution that oppressed black people he says many of the confederate monuments were built from the through the an era when civil war veterans were dying and their descendants were eager to honor them it was also the era immediately following reconstruction when federal troops abandoned the south and whites aimed to reassert power through jim crow laws lynchings and groups such as the ku klux klan granite and marble monuments proclaimed that power often in the center of town but even in majority black city on the eastern shore of the state whitaker has battled to get portsmouth monument removed last summer attorney fred taylor who also represented confederate in the danville case warned the city that state law prohibited it from moving the monument we believe the monument protection act covers the monument in danville covers the monument in portsmouth taylor says he argues that the original virginia statute protecting war monuments dates back to so there has been protection all along when the circuit court judge ruled against him in danville taylor appealed the case to the virginia supreme court so far the court has not agreed to hear the case back in portsmouth the debate continues some residents don want the city to spend upward of to move the monument position whitaker finds ridiculous why now when we talk about moving symbol of racism we re concerned about cost he says the portsmouth city council had been waiting to hear the outcome of the danville court case but could resume its discussion of the monument after the november elections we re on solid legal grounds to remove it he says we just need four votes other virginia cities have struck middle ground forming committees to figure out what to do with their confederate monuments in may charlottesville convened blue ribbon commission on race memorials and public spaces although the move was sparked by controversial statue of robert lee in public park mayor mike signer was determined to broaden the conversation with an eye toward changing the city entire historic landscape he asked the commission to look at several landmarks from an african american cemetery that had fallen into disrepair to the statue of confederate boy in front of the courthouse members of the panel have discussed rehabbing and creating new historic interpretations for these sites building new monuments to african american leaders and linking all the sites so that visitors can see how they are connected there might even be virtual mobile educational component to help people navigate the sites the goal signer says is to change the narrative of charlottesville by telling the full story of race through our public spaces the commission is slated to give its recommendations to the city council in december in the wealthy heavily democratic city of alexandria similar advisory group decided not to remove the appomattox statue in the middle of old town which depicts defeated confederate soldier with his eyes downcast the united daughters of the confederacy owns the monument and moving it would require approval from the virginia general assembly also as the advisory group noted appomattox is one of the rare confederate statues that marks historic site the place where the th virginia regiment gathered to withdraw from union occupation of the city in the group recommended labeling the statue with more historical context instead of taking it down black lives matter is spray painted on monument to former confederate president jefferson davis in richmond virginia in june ap photo richmond the former capital of the confederacy has an entire street lined with monuments to confederate leaders it also majority black city in june someone scrawled black lives matter on the statue of former confederate president jefferson davis yet mayor dwight jones has not called for the monuments removal instead he suggested adding more statues of prominent black leaders such as the bronze of tennis legend arthur ashe who was born in richmond that the city erected in rather than tearing down we should be building up in ways that establish proper sense of balance and fairness by recognizing heroes from all eras to tell richer and more accurate story of virginia history jones said in statement last summer delegate poindexter tends to agree with jones although he fuzzy on the specifics asked whether he would be in favor of adding more historical context to existing confederate monuments he says it far better than tearing down the current ones in his eyes the era in which the confederate monuments were erected is irrelevant they need to be respected he says they didn know what we know today that why these monuments are important ayers says many people who push to preserve confederate monuments share this attitude the white south has always been on the defensive ever since it tried to leave the united states he says they ve taken what ground they can get and what they can get is personal memory and memorialization it an amalgam of power and weakness they re meant to do work ayers says the work that they were meant to do in some ways they re still doing saying that this is place where local white people call the shots in franklin county the power struggle is deeply personal stanley says the area sent about confederate soldiers to what she calls the war between the states veterans who returned home became mayors and town clerks and delegates beginning in the local chapter of the united daughters of the confederacy started raising money for memorial to honor the sons fathers and husbands who never made it home they dedicated the monument in front of the courthouse in one of the people who agreed to donate money to the project was booker washington the famed african american educator who was born into slavery on farm in franklin county in in he wrote letter offering to contribute funds for the confederate memorial in honor of the family that owned him as far as stanley knows washington did contribute some amount we just don have copy of the actual check poindexter says franklin county lost hundreds of its best men in the civil war and for decades afterward reconstruction was horrible process that had big impact on the region today franklin county is home to about people percent of whom are white they elected poindexter conservative christian with an rating from the national rifle association to the general assembly for the first time in in the county had median household income of far below the state median of its residents voted republican in the past three presidential races and many supported poindexter efforts to save war monuments we didn want anybody pulling any monuments down stanley says soon after the county replaced the confederate memorial in front of the courthouse the local chapter of the naacp suggested that statue of booker washington be erected beside it other community leaders wanted to put up pedestal honoring african americans who contributed to the county civil war effort the county board of supervisors tabled their request saying the community needed more time to discuss it civil war memorials are not generally big tourist draw in the roanoke region says landon howard president of visit virginia blue ridge to be candid we really do not get hardly any american civil war visitation here yet locals have their own loyalties every year the franklin county historical society celebrates veterans memorial day honoring all local casualties of military conflicts according to the society website special emphasis is placed on veterans of the war between the states as this war touched literally every household in the county confederate general jubal early was born in franklin county and he known as one of the rebels who never surrendered he became the primary spokesman for the lost cause and became the overwhelming authority on published confederate history says the website of the jubal early homeplace speaking by phone from his farm in franklin county poindexter isn ready to surrender either he doesn know whether he ll propose his monument protection bill again next year but he hasn ruled it out if you start tearing down monuments where do you stop he says you can change what was but you can learn from it and not make that mistake again lisa rab is journalist in charlotte her work has appeared in mother jones and the village voice among other outlets reach her at lisayrab gmail com
monuments to the battle for the new south

milquetoast positions mrs clinton wants to increase turnout among african americans and women by tackling issues of bias and respect mr trump is positioning himself at the vanguard of white men ii why donald trump should not be president donald trump is man who dwells in bigotry bluster and false promises when donald trump began his improbable run for president months ago he offered his wealth and television celebrity as credentials then slyly added twist of fearmongering about mexican rapists flooding across the southern border from that moment of combustion it became clear that mr trump views were matters of dangerous impulse and cynical pandering rather than thoughtful politics yet he has attracted throngs of americans who ascribe higher purpose to him than he has demonstrated in freewheeling campaign marked by bursts of false and outrageous allegations personal insults xenophobic nationalism unapologetic sexism and positions that shift according to his audience and his giuliani slams lester holt for fact checking like candy crowley presidential debate moderator lester holt pulled two candy crowleys former new york mayor rudy giuliani said tuesday accusing of the nbc nightly news anchor of mirroring crowley infamous mitt romney fact check twice on monday night in an interview with fox and friends giuliani said he watched the debate two times once live and then went home and watched lester holt do candy crowley at least twice story continued below donald trump who had suggested debate without moderator ahead of monday faceoff warned holt last week not to be like crowley who interrupted romney in after the then republican nominee said it took president barack obama days to call the attack in benghazi libya an act of terror politifact rated romney criticism half true noting that obama did say act of terror right after the attacks but that the administration did not speak consistently in the days that followed giuliani took issue with holt ignorantly attempting to fact check trump on the of stop and frisk and the real estate mogul false assertion that he never supported the iraq war federal judge in new york ruled the application of the practice not the policy itself as holt suggested giuliani argued the thing that wrong is lester holt said straight out stop and frisk is lester holt is not lawyer giuliani said he wrong it was decided in by earl warren it is still the law of the land the former mayor maintained that every cop does stop and frisk in every part of america but gave hillary clinton pass for siding with holt because she failed the bar exam but not gonna allow him to play lawyer and contradict our candidate he continued and like to know when did moderator become fact checker and if you re gonna be fact checker you better darn be right lawyer not moderator who misrepresents on television giuliani said after co steve doocy noted that giuliani was fact checking holt lawyer am angry about it thought after candy crowley we saw the last of it what holt did last night if journalism has ethics if it has ethics he violated the rules of ethics now if you re gonna interrupt and you re gonna correct me in front of million people you better be right he is dead wrong giuliani continued this verbal broadside slamming holt for being completely unprofessional and totally unethical and suggesting that he should have had enough energy to check the sources regarding whether trump supported the iraq war saw the tape and he opposed the iraq war before the iraq war giuliani said despite numerous fact checks that note laced into the texas senator for throwing his support behind donald trump late last week for the very first time heard ted cruz calculate and when that happened the whole thing fell apart for me and it my fault beck said on his radio show story continued below it my fault beck continued should have said you know who can win you know who could beat hillary clinton marco rubio and disagree with him on the gang of eight and there about percent that do agree with him on and he kind of politician but he different kind of politician he young politician he hispanic he can win let go for it instead beck sought truly honorable man in cruz and that will always let you down he said but while lamenting the fact that cruz chose to be politician friday beck said that he believes the texas firebrand is still good man not gonna condemn him he is still believe good man beck said he is just politician first ve never put him into the category of politician and that my fault he is politician for his part cruz insisted to beck monday that he was trying to show the trump campaign how to earn his vote with his floor speech at the republican national convention in which he encouraged republicans to vote their conscience in november after beck noted that cruz failed to answer question this past weekend about whether the real estate mogul was fit to be president the senator explained that the presidential election is binary choice conclusion he reached after whittling down five possible options vote for trump for clinton third party candidate write in candidate or abstain so man who has principles who says there are lines will not cross it still binary choice so man who you cannot come on and say yes glenn he is fit to be president of the united states still am encouraged by you to abandon my principles and vote because it binary choice beck asked you are encouraged by me to do what you believe is right and honorable in principle cruz shot back warning of the damage he said clinton would do to america beck however wasn satisfied this is information that you had in cleveland and hang on just second before you respond you had all of this information you had this information the day you dropped out of the race and said that donald trump is sociopathic liar beck said so you had all this information have you spent an enormous amount of time with donald trump do you have new information that has made you say oh my gosh he now not sociopathic liar he is not the guy very eloquently spelled out for over year and now suddenly there reason to believe him despite his significant disagreements with trump cruz said it binary choice asking for new information asking you for new information beck said you knew all the things that you re saying today the time to do that would have been the day you pulled out or the day that you gave the speech so eloquently why now what new cruz pointed to the trump campaign release of possible conservative supreme court nominees list that includes cruz ally utah sen mike lee he suggested he had hand in the list noting that the supreme court was an issue he raised with vice presidential nominee mike pence when he asked the texas senator what it would take to get him on board we discussed the supreme court as being one of the great checks protecting the constitution and the rule of law and the trump campaign committing to nominate from that list was an important change that gave me significant reassurance that helped me get to the point of saying yes cruz said after stu burguiere pressed cruz on why he would believe anything trump says he rattled off series of principles at stake now with respect to the justices donald trump would nominate know that he is publicly committing to nominate from list that is very strong and if he were to nominate from that list it would be major step towards protecting our rights cruz said hope that he would follow through on that commitment one never knows if one will but the fact that he is public promising will nominate from these think creates dynamic where compared to hillary who is promising to put left wing ideologues that clear choice cruz also disagreed with the wide interpretation that his rnc remarks were swipe against trump adding that he always been never hillary but not ever never trump he also said he gleaned parts of his speech from what ronald reagan said about gerald ford and what ted kennedy said about jimmy carter my speech drew deliberately from both of those speeches cruz said both of those speeches at the time were treated effectively as endorsement speeches one of the unfortunate things about the reaction is cleveland is that for many who were watching it was perceived that was essentially embracing never trump have never been never trumper after cruz appearance beck said cruz would have been better of just telling the truth about why he backed trump he could have come on and said look guys here the thing my supporters are yelling at me and know that because so are mine he said my donors who are all in with the gop they re all saying ll never fund won fund you for the senate won fund you for the run in and have to make decision so the question is do completely shut myself out of this game or do play the game as much as possibly can authors

on the night of september as the house lights dim in the mack complex at hofstra university and the tv cameras go live millions of americans will be riveted to the scene will donald trump seem well prepared will hillary clinton commanding grasp of policy and nuance dazzle viewers will either candidate rise to the challenge and show voters that they have what it takes to be president experience suggests it hard to make positive breakthrough especially with two candidates so well known and so widely disliked but what is possible is serious unforced error story continued below over the years that presidential debates have been televised one of their great legacies has been the sudden public gaffe mistake live on tv that permanently cements the way voters see the candidate despite the hopeful aspirations of those voters who welcome few hours of substantive deliberation on the major issues of the day the truth is that these are televised performances what the candidates say often matters less than how they look and what they do with their bodies every breath they take every expression they make and every emotion they convey can play major role in determining how americans evaluate their performances and although debates don usually transform how most voters think of the candidates they do confirm voters impressions which matters on election day for both candidates this will be particularly big challenge donald trump is larger than life presence who likes to intimidate cajole and verbally bully his opponents by saying things long considered out of bounds which could lead to an unforced error by hillary clinton hillary clinton who sometimes betrays an aversion to letting too much emotion show has steely temperament and stinging wit that could easily get under trump skin instigating him into losing control with the cameras rolling if either of these happens it will join the long line of memorable campaign changing moments that candidates fumbled into nixon sweats while debating jfk famously the very first televised presidential debate offered early evidence that all future debates would be visual affairs after eight years as vice president richard nixon was running to inherit the white house from the enormously popular dwight eisenhower his challenger was john kennedy the charismatic young massachusetts senator whose eloquence and matinee idol looks captivated much of the nation on september at the candidates first debate nixon proved to be in strong command of policy but he looked terrible famously prior to the debate he declined to have any makeup applied to his face but that decision was made worse by the fact that for much of the previous two weeks nixon had been away from the campaign trail nursing knee infection as result he looked peaked video the biggest unforced errors in debate history from richard nixon sweating on camera during the first presidential debate to george bush checking his watch before an audience question here are some of the most prominent debate gaffes in history during their televised rumble nixon could be seen sweating and on camera wiping his brow with handkerchief his pale color and five clock shadow didn help all of which undercut his performance against kennedy who was vision of youthful vigor ford and carter freeze in moment of crisis more dramatic moment occurred on september when the sound system malfunctioned in philadelphia walnut street theater forcing minute delay during the debate during which president gerald ford and then governor jimmy carter awkwardly stood still on stage the broadcast continued as the television crew worked furiously to fix the technical problems neither candidate wanted to move fearing that it would somehow look bad to audiences at home so instead they stood frozen in comic parody better than anything that saturday night live could imagine moderators robert mcneil and jim lehrer kept talking as the candidates stood helplessly like two hollywood stand ins wrote jules witcover in the washington post years later ford admitted that suspect both of us would have liked to sit down and relax while the technicians were fixing the system but think both of us were hesitant to make any gesture that might look like we weren physically or mentally able to handle problem like this in the end both men were diminished they seemed less like leaders than deer caught in headlights carter grim faced critiques seem too self serious in politics brevity can be virtue during his only debate with ronald reagan in the fall of jimmy carter didn get that lesson in front of record breaking million viewers carter was hoping to paint ronald reagan as creature of the far right someone like barry goldwater the gop nominee whom lyndon johnson so successfully branded as an extremist some years earlier as reagan sought to present himself as more moderate relatable republican carter tried to forcefully punch back in the form of lengthy and detailed monologue about health care and how reagan had opposed medicare in while carter looked grim on the attack reagan grinned like mildly disappointed father and shot back with just one phrase there you go again he said with laugh the line undercut carter entire argument making reagan look like the bigger man mondale lets reagan one liner negate serious weakness during first debate reagan then aroused concern when he seemed to have trouble remembering his answers or following the questions he stumbled over his words and lacked clarity with each statement his opponent former vice president walter mondale was crisp and sharp in contrast reagan rambled through his closing statement to the alarm of his advisers lou cannon wrote that reagan left the stage admitting to campaign adviser stu spencer that he had flopped the wall street journal headline the next morning captured the zeitgeist new question in race is oldest president now showing his age fortunately for reagan he came back with vengeance in later debate when baltimore sun journalist henry trewitt asked reagan if his age would prevent him from fulfilling the rigors of the presidency reagan had quip for the ages will not make age an issue in this campaign will not exploit for political purposes my opponent youth and inexperience the audience erupted in laughter including mondale which completely undercut the seriousness of the underlying charge dukakis seems cold in the face of deeply personal question perhaps the most shocking and controversial opening question in any presidential debate was posed by cnn anchor bernard shaw to massachusetts gov michael dukakis at the second debate of dukakis was widely seen as technocrat man whose inner character remained mystery to many voters the night before the debate at shaw thought of the question that could crack that shell and elicit passion from the candidate and so he began the debate with it governor if kitty dukakis were raped and murdered would you favor an irrevocable death penalty for the killer reporters were shocked but dukakis seemed unperturbed in clinical and dispassionate manner dukakis simply said no don bernard and think you know that ve opposed the death penalty during all of my life don see any evidence that it deterrent and think there are better and more effective ways to deal with violent crime it was as though dukakis was talking about stranger answering in the same tone that professor might use to explain basic point of fact in the classroom voters were taken aback by how little passion the candidate seemed to have it was question about dukakis values and emotions his campaign director susan estrich later recalled when he answered by talking policy knew we lost the election bush checks his watch while an audience member asks question during the campaign few moments were more devastating to george bush than his decision to look at his wrist watch in the middle of town hall debate with bill clinton and ross perot right before an audience member asked the candidates how the national debt personally affected the lives of the candidates and how they could relate to the economic challenges of average americans bush was seen looking down to figure out how many minutes were left only more minutes of this crap bush would later say he was thinking at the time checking the time would ve been unflattering in normal debate setup but coming as it did during debate in which ordinary americans posed questions to the presidential candidates it seemed like bush was bored and uninterested in hearing what real people had to say for candidate already under attack for not being concerned about domestic policy his glance seemed to confirm everything that was said about him gore sighs eye rolls and miscalculates in confrontation with bush entering the debates in vice president al gore and his supporters were pretty confident that they were up against political lightweight in george bush gore had been in high profile debates before and his team was confident that the debates would show american voters that bush relative lightweight known to stumble over his words lacked the clarity and gravitas needed to be president during the first debate gore overdramatic attempts to emphasize how exasperated he was with bush backfired big time at several points microphones caught gore loudly sighing in response to bush answers which played into republican arguments that he was arrogant and condescending and as bush criticized the democrat plans for their fuzzy math gore was seen on the split screen rolling his eyes and shaking his head in frustration at the third debate town hall style affair one of the oddest moments of this or any other debate happened gore walked right up to bush as he was speaking as if to physically intimidate him looking up with an annoyed glance bush seized the moment nodding his head with smirk and continuing on with his statement making gore action look odd as the audience laughed donna brazile who ran gore campaign believed that gore won the debates on policy but on mannerisms and the takeaway he ended up losing many of us remember the split screen and al gore was sitting there rolling his eyes perhaps looking at george bush and basically he started to sigh bush cannot contain his irritation at kerry after the first debate of the general election in president bush came under criticism when he couldn contain how annoyed he was by some of the comments his opponent senator john kerry made about bush record though bush had benefited from the visuals of his debates against vice president al gore the critics weren so kind to bush in when cameras caught him scowling clenching his jaw and leaning tensely over his lectern as he listened to kerry speak the democratic national committee didn wait long to pounce on the president in their online video faces of frustration viewers were treated to repeat of the split screen showing kerry calmly speaking on the left side of the screen with bush angry looks on the right side appearances are not the only thing that matters in the debates of course what the candidates say will be endlessly scrutinized with the media while the quality of the one line zingers particularly in the viral age of twitter facebook and youtube are important in shaping perceptions of the event and on september years to the day since nixon awkwardly sweated his way through the debate with jfk we ll see what happens julian zelizer is political historian at princeton university and political reform fellow at new america he is the author of the fierce urgency of now lyndon johnson congress and the battle for the great society penguin press
the biggest unforced errors in debate history
donald trump is calling for one of the most controversial and racially charged policies enacted by police departments to be expanded across the entire country the city of new york recently ended stop and frisk but trump is pushing for it apparently egged on by his top campaign surrogate former new york city mayor rudy giuliani from politico in pre taped interview on fox news scheduled to air wednesday night trump was asked by an audience member what he would do to address violence in the black community and black on black crime trump responded by proposing that stop and frisk policing in which an officer is empowered to stop an individual and frisk them for weapons or any other illegal contraband be adopted nationwide would do stop and frisk think you have to we did it in new york it worked incredibly well and you have to be proactive and you know you really help people sort of change their mind automatically trump told the questioner stop and frisk was repeatedly called out and protested against by new york city residents because the policy was shown time and time again to target black and latino residents they were singled out for examination and interrogation by police officers in what some felt were quotas set up by police management when the city stopped using stop and frisk they did not see an increase in crime despite claims from its supporters that there would be spike in criminal activity most people who had been subject to stop and frisk were let go because they hadn done anything wrong former us district court judge shira scheindlin who had ruled the procedure in federal court described it as destructive in an interview with buzzfeed she added in short the overstopping in many communities harmed the relationship between the people and the police cooperation has now improved due to positive efforts by police to work with the community not against it featured image via flickr
trump calls for this racist policy to be forced on every state

ap photo backtalk robert kennedy would have hated donald trump the gop candidate is not the man of peace my former colleague makes him out to be writing as former legislative assistant to senator robert kennedy and an enthusiastic supporter of hillary clinton for president was disappointed to see in politico the screed written by my former colleague adam walinsky excoriating clinton record on foreign policy and national security and going on to conclude that donald trump should therefore be elected president it is one thing to disagree with secretary clinton which walinsky does heatedly and quite another to turn to donald trump we should be clear that walinsky critique is not confined to clinton he lays out and massively overstates dark view not just of clinton but also of president obama and almost the entire democratic party the analysis is overwrought but even one who buys the argument defies all logic in imagining that the solution is trump story continued below the question is not whether there is military industrial complex in our country president eisenhower called us out on that and there is enough responsibility to go around among both parties for it the st century version begins with the iraq war which was originated by republican president am not interested in adjudicating the issue of which party is the war party except to say that presidents obama clinton and carter have stood for peace in important and tangible ways the question here is whether donald trump can claim in any way that he is the candidate who stands for foreign policy of restraint and the answer is that he cannot walinsky finds in trump rationality and consistency that do not exist any reasonable observer of the presidential campaign has seen that at one moment trump will represent himself as an isolationist who wants to end ties with nato and other allies at another he will lash out at any perceived insult to the or to himself and pledges that america pride needs to be vindicated militarily america first trump says regularly bringing the isolationism of charles lindbergh to mind before excoriating president obama for not using greater force in any number of venues and then insinuating that he has secret plan to obliterate the islamic state to compare john kennedy and robert kennedy to donald trump is well won finish the sentence yes robert kennedy turned against the vietnam war but not because he felt that america should retreat from the world he opposed the war because it was unjust and was based on flawed notion of american interests the result as we know was the death of vietnamese and americans and others who should not have died jfk and rfk were they understood that world war ii left the united states with responsibility to play an active and constructive role in the world they understood that america must stand together and dependably with allies who also are committed to pursue peaceful world they understood that the use of force was sometimes necessary and that brave men and women would be put at risk they made those difficult often excruciating decisions carefully and as transparently as possible never rashly impulsively or vindictively walinsky quotes robert kennedy statement that if any member of the excomm other than john kennedy had been president during the cuban missile crisis we would have had nuclear war ask yourself what president trump might have done in that moment restraint is not the word that comes to mind this is man who said he would order the military to kill the families of muslim terrorists and use interrogation techniques worse than waterboarding and opined that the united states should have seized iraq oil resources as spoils to the victor yes we have put too much power in the hands of militarists and profit seekers in both the public and private sectors but electing donald trump is not the answer it would only compound the problem in new and dangerous ways the answer is an active citizenry that speaks out against the inappropriate use of force and opposes interference in conflicts that involve neither american security interests nor egregious human rights violations topic in which donald trump has shown an ostentatious indifference as his fondness for vladimir putin reflects all the evidence provided again and again by donald trump own mouth tells us not that he is man of peace but that he is man of no principle man who will say and possibly do whatever happens to cross his mind at given minute he is like the weather in new england if you don like it wait minute we do not know what he believes because he does not know what he believes we do not know what he knows because from all we can see he does not know much even if walinsky diatribe is correct which it most certainly is not in its breadth and depth there is nothing in it that justifies turning to donald trump of all occasions to break ranks with the democratic party this is the most inappropriate of all the ways to misappropriate the memory of john and robert kennedy two of our greatest public servants this is the most egregious have ever seen to say that am disappointed by what walinsky has done is an understatement america in this election faces an existential question and history will judge us by our answer walinsky has chosen the wrong side of the struggle peter edelman is the carmack waterhouse professor of law and public policy at georgetown university law center
robert kennedy would have hated donald trump
billionaire who built up corporate empire from his father inheritance now is running his first major political campaign with promise to shake up the establishment and restore prosperity after long period of stagnation but in this case it not donald trump it jim justice the democratic candidate for governor in west virginia and coal baron to boot like trump justice has been accused of not paying his bills and being out mainly for himself and like trump justice is running nontraditional campaign that exists well outside the partisan pattern eschewing hillary clinton and barack obama in favor of cult of personality based around his exploits in business as west virginia only billionaire he can self fund pumping million into his campaign through mid june justice faces stiff crosswinds however running as down ballot democrat in one of trump strongest states story continued below west virginia polling is scarce and often inaccurate but metronews west virginia poll released earlier this month showed trump with advantage over hillary clinton who won only percent to bernie sanders percent in the state may primary in an era of declining split ticket voting justice must outperform clinton by double digits to win that led to dynamic in which west virginia gop candidate for governor state senate president bill cole is embracing trump while justice is distancing himself from clinton it very nearly the opposite of what happening in other states with close races across the nation democrats are trying to nationalize their races because they think they can use trump as weapon in this race it pretty clear democrats are trying to localize because trump is not drag but an asset for cole says kyle kondik managing editor of larry sabato crystal ball at the university of virginia center for politics this is one of the few places in the country where republicans are more concerned with nationalizing race than democrats are in this race trump isn drag on republicans he an asset the reason is simple coal republicans have dominated appalachia the past three cycles by bludgeoning democrats with war on coal rhetoric blaming obama for the industry decline it hard to make that charge stick against coal baron and justice definitely qualifies he inherited an array of coal interests from his father then enlarged them to become one of the biggest private coal mine owners in the east that growth included the sale of his bluestone coal corp to russia oao mechel for million then the coal slump hit and last year justice bought bluestone back for million less than percent of his selling price cole the republican candidate has more elective experience than justice but he no establishment insider owner of bill cole automall and other businesses cole is finishing only his first term in the west virginia senate having previously served few months in the house of delegates when he was appointed to fill vacant seat however cole spent much of wrapped up in state budget crisis and has focused his general election campaign on tried and true conservative policy proposals such as cutting spending and taxes banning late term abortions and opening charter schools in year in which voters largely have embraced personality over policy that may not be enough even in republican tilting state with wildly popular candidate at the top of the ticket if you think about the primary races here we saw giant trump win and giant sanders win says scott crichlow associate professor of political science at west virginia university if you look at trump look at sanders look at justice they certainly have policies that are known the wall universal health care the coal industry but so much of what driving the appeal for them is personality and image not just list of policy prescriptions justice is running as conservative democrat not unlike former governor and current sen joe manchin with whom he shares number of campaign staff he flip flopped between the two major parties giving money to both and changing his registration most recently in february when he became democrat however he says he won vote for clinton and dismissed cole claim that he supports obama as complete dog snot and while justice spokesman grant herring says his candidate isn focused on the national political circus the language he uses to describe his appeal sounds awfully familiar jim is no politician says herring he is the outsider in this race who has the skills and experience to transform the state at the moment it looks like that approach is working metronews west virginia poll released september showed justice running away with the race at percent cole with percent mountain party candidate charlotte pritt with percent and libertarian david moran with percent many doubt the veracity of the metronews poll which has varied wildly when measured against election results in recent years but most including cole spokesman kent gates agree that justice is winning do think justice has lead yes says gates do think it double digits no some of that is because justice industry ties largely make him resistant to the gop otherwise effective war on coal messaging which has proven to be democrat kryptonite around appalachia even in districts beyond the coalfields if you re going to win in west virginia you better be running against hillary clinton says dave mudcat saunders western virginia political consultant known for his so called bubba strategy designed to help democrats appeal to white working class voters saunders who has said he voting for trump says voters don trust clinton or care about her support for funding going to help coalfield economies transition to something else she said she going to put coal out of business west virginia coal miners don want handout they want their dignity they want their jobs if you re going to win in west virginia you better be running against hillary clinton says one democratic strategist but saunders doesn have kind words for justice either he screwed every coal operator in west virginia at one time or another cole sees that reputation as his big opening his spokesman gates says the republican campaign will open up attacks on justice business record over the next several weeks jim justice is coal operator but he not coal operator acting in the best interest of west virginia gates says his legacy of unpaid bills is documented across the land that record extends from unpaid federal fines to unpaid vendors to unpaid state and local taxes in multiple states in series on delinquent mines npr reported that justice stands out among mining operators owing nearly million in unpaid fines at the time that same year federal agency issued cessation orders against three justice companies for reclamation violations at tennessee mines including hiring contractor who planted trees upside down the problems have persisted this year in kentucky justice mines missed reclamation deadlines and owed nearly million in delinquent property taxes that an improvement from last year when he owed million in unpaid kentucky taxes in southwest virginia tazewell county officials seized machinery tools and other equipment from justice owned mine this spring to make up for in unpaid property taxes when west virginia property taxes became delinquent in april justice owed more than million the pattern apparently extends to justice other businesses as well two companies sued the greenbrier for unpaid work on its golf courses for the pga tournament eventually settling out of court justice mining record which includes extensive use of mountaintop removal mining as well as his issues with mine reclamation has made him the target of many an appalachian environmental activist the cole campaign going negative on justice might not push those green voters to vote republican but it might tip them toward pritt who is running for governor as the candidate of the mountain party the west virginia affiliate of the green party pritt served eight years in the state legislature and is making her third run for governor the last time she ran in she defeated manchin in primary on the way to loss in the general election both cole and justice have promised to bring back coal jobs but whoever wins in november faces the monumental task of state economy that suffered mightily with the collapse of the coal industry according to the census west virginia median household income was compared with nationally its poverty rate was percent versus nationally mining jobs have plummeted falling percent in the past calendar year percent from decade ago and percent from when the market for metallurgical or steel making coal spiked on the strength of then strong asian economy mines sit idle as string of industry giants alpha natural resources arch coal patriot coal peabody energy and walter energy filed for bankruptcy due to convergence of factors including slumping asian economy competition from cheap natural gas and federal clean air regulations that resulted in wave of older power plants closing or converting to natural gas while the market for metallurgical or steel making coal may eventually return it unlikely the same will be true for steam or power producing coal the coal industry struggles haven just hurt west virginia employment rate but also its state budget the reduction in coal and natural gas severance tax collection contributed to its budget crisis along with an economy that generally has failed to transition from its fossil fuel roots in this gubernatorial campaign neither candidate seems eager to push that process forward justice however has experience operating in economic sectors such as farming and tourism that may be part of the recipe for recovery he previously owned wintergreen resort in virginia before selling it last year and in he bought the famed greenbrier resort out of bankruptcy since then he brought an annual pga tournament and the new orleans saints training camp to the greenbrier in late june month and half after justice won the democratic nomination and two weeks before the greenbrier classic pga tournament was scheduled to start tragedy inadvertently threw spotlight on the greenbrier and the communities around it when west virginia was slammed by historic rains and flooding that qualified as year event in parts of the state twenty three people were killed including in greenbrier county and hundreds of homes were destroyed justice canceled the pga event and closed the greenbrier resort though it opened its doors free of charge to house about people who had been displaced from their homes he shut down his campaign for roughly days following the flooding appearing only at brief press conference to announce the greenbrier reopening date should he win in november however his response to the flooding and actions at the greenbrier will be remembered as defining moment whether justice will win however remains an open question double digit poll lead notwithstanding sabato crystal ball recently moved the west virginia governor race from leans republican to toss up we re being cautious because of the fact that justice will need to run so far ahead of clinton kondik says trump will easily win west virginia but the winner of the governor race will be determined by how willing voters are to split their tickets and whether democrats remain loyal to their party or break for pritt that why cole campaign is attacking justice on his record as coal businessman even as they decry the federal war on coal whether those voters go to cole or to pritt ultimately doesn matter so long as they re not voting for justice in his attacks on justice cole spokesman gates repeated one line couple of times at the end of the day jim justice is going to do what best for jim justice that line has been used about donald trump too the question for west virginia voters on election day will be whether what in justice and trump best interests is in theirs too mason adams writes from southwest virginia he on twitter at masonatoms

in total states and the district of columbia will allow early voting in ap photo when does early voting start in every state voting has already started in scattering of locations and entire states will be able to vote starting friday election day is more than month away but voters are already casting ballots to pick their next president voting opened on monday in wisconsin rapids wisconsin making the town voters among the first in the nation to do so so far voting is limited to smattering of counties and municipalities in states that allow local governments to set their own schedules on friday however voters statewide in south dakota and minnesota will be allowed to cast early ballots and other states are joining soon new jersey starts early voting on saturday and vermont plans to start early voting as soon as the ballots are ready state rules say no later than saturday story continued below in total states and the district of columbia will allow early voting in some of those states allow voters to request mail ballots and send them in while others open physical polling places weeks or even months before the election in the presidential election approximately percent of the votes cast came via mail or early balloting meaning many voters will weigh in before the candidates have had chance to make their closing case typically democrats lead in early voting especially in person early voting because their voters are not as likely to go out to the polls as republicans said michael mcdonald an election expert and associate professor at the university of florida the gop however tends to make up ground through mail in absentee ballots mcdonald said here when early voting begins in each state note the below dates represent the earliest date that voters statewide can send for ballot or vote in person without special exemption alabama there no universal early voting in alabama as voters need state approved excuse to vote absentee alaska oct arizona oct local counties are still finalizing the locations where voters can vote in person but ballots for mail in voting begin going out on the th arkansas oct california early voting opening dates are set by the county municipality oct is the first day to vote early in los angeles county colorado oct connecticut there is no early voting in connecticut as voters need state approved excuse to vote absentee district of columbia oct at one judiciary square oct for all other locations delaware there is no early voting in delaware as voters need state approved excuse to vote absentee florida all counties are required to allow voting from oct to nov some have the option to start earlier georgia oct voters can sign up for an absentee ballot starting sept hawaii oct idaho sept counties must send out absentee ballot requests no later than the rd but are allowed to offer early voting early voting opening dates are set by the county municipality illinois sept to nov starting sept voters can only cast their ballots at their local election authority or temporary location but early voting expands to permanent polling places starting oct indiana oct early voting starts at the local county election board office or another designated location but with an excuse voters can cast ballot by mail iowa sept kansas oct counties are allowed to set earlier extended early voting dates kentucky there is no early voting in kentucky unless voters have state approved excuse to vote absentee louisiana oct to nov maine oct is the general opening date but the state allows you to vote as soon as the ballots are printed and some people have already cast their ballots maryland oct to nov massachusetts oct to nov michigan there is no early voting in michigan as voters require state approved excuse to vote absentee minnesota sept mississippi there is no early voting in mississippi as voters need state approved excuse to vote absentee missouri there is no early voting in missouri as voters need state approved excuse to vote absentee montana in person early voting begins as soon as ballots are ready which is expected to be around oct nebraska oct the counties mail out requests starting on the rd but the first day to vote early in person is oct nevada oct new hampshire there is no early voting in new hampshire unless voters have state approved excuse to vote absentee new jersey sept in person early voting may begin sooner it starts as soon as ballots are available but mail in ballots are sent out beginning on the th new mexico oct to nov voters can apply for an absentee ballot on oct but starting on the nd they can vote early in person new york there is no early voting in new york as voters require state approved excuse to vote absentee north carolina sept oct to nov absentee ballots have already been sent out but the formal early voting period does not start until october north dakota sept absentee and mail ballots can be sent out by county officials starting on the th but the exact date might vary from one location to the next ohio oct oklahoma nov to nov oregon oct pennsylvania there is no early voting in pennsylvania as voters need state approved excuse to vote absentee rhode island there is no early voting in rhode island unless voters have state approved excuse to vote absentee south carolina there is no early voting in south carolina unless voters have state approved excuse to vote absentee the state does however give voters more absentee leeway than many south dakota sept tennessee oct to nov texas oct to nov utah oct to nov virginia there is no early voting in virginia unless voters have state approved excuse to vote absentee vermont sept to nov early voting could start before the rd but it will not begin any later than that date washington spoke on condition of anonymity because they were not authorized to talk about the ongoing investigation no one has been charged and the investigation is continuing langmesser said cuomo touring the site of saturday blast in chelsea said the unexploded pressure cooker device appeared similar in design to the bomb that exploded in chelsea on sunday federal law enforcement official said the chelsea bomb contained residue of tannerite an explosive often used for target practice that can be picked up in many sporting goods stores the discovery of tannerite may be important as authorities probe whether the two new york city devices and the pipe bomb at the jersey shore are connected cellphones were discovered at the site of both bombings but no tannerite residue was identified in the new jersey bomb remnants in which black powder was detected said the official who wasn authorized to comment on an ongoing investigation and spoke to the ap on condition of anonymity the pipe bomb is being built to prevent illegal migrants from jumping onto vehicles preparing to cross the english channel the wall will cost an estimated two million pounds about million and will be approximately feet high there is nearby migrant camp called the jungle that has been attacking vehicles in an attempt to climb aboard lorries and cars in order to enter the united kingdom the wall will be made out of concrete which is more difficult to climb and will be extended by fences things all young adults should know by sir john hawkins john hawkins book things all young adults should know is filled with digestible chapters buy now the jungle now has more than migrants and it has become hotspot for violence police have called that area of calais no go zone after dark due to the endemic violence in the area the migrants have been known to cause car crashes leave debris on the road thrown rocks off of bridges and started fires they have also physically attacked drivers with bats stabbed them with knives and even threatened people with chainsaws it is these attacks that encouraged calais port chief executive jean marc puissesseau to support the wall this wall is going to prevent migrants from kallstadt germany few places in germany are as representative of the country heartland as kallstadt the village in which republican presidential candidate donald trump grandfather was born and from which he was later deported the hamlet of people lies nestled among vineyard covered hills about an hour and half drive southwest of frankfurt it has one bakery and one butcher every year kallstadt holds the saumagenkerwe in celebration of the eponymous local delicacy pig stomach filled with pork herbs bratwurst and diced potatoes trump may have captured large swath of the american electorate with his signature blend of populism nativism and brazenness and yet in the hometown of his forefather he remains distinctly unpopular in fact few politicians are less popular in germany than trump study by the pew research center found out that only percent of the country finds him trustworthy since local newspaper discovered that johannes steiniger member of the german parliament was distantly related to trump the year old has done all he can to distance himself from the presidential candidate with his statements about gay people and foreigners or with the language he uses and with his derogative statements about hillary clinton trump seems to do everything he can so that we get negative image of him steiniger tells politico trump rhetoric regarding immigrants and racial minorities is especially unpopular in kallstadt he stands for everything that bad says sarah hler yelling to be heard over the person brass band celebrating the saumagenkerwe in the town main square hler is former local wine princess the victor of beauty pageant to promote the local wine industry this year new dish appeared in the town annual festival saumagen ner fusion of the local specialty with turkish kebab everyone is welcome to join us here no matter what color they are says hler pink purple doesn matter tanja huber the year old incumbent regional wine princess nods her head in agreement since the prospect of trump presidency first became evident late last year reporters have descended on kallstadt seeking bit of local color quote or two and perhaps some hometown pride they don get that we really don give damn about trump says huber he never been here and he apparently doesn care about us either donald grandfather friedrich trump was born in kallstadt into vintner family on march previous generations of the trump family used variant spellings of the name including trump dromb and trumpff according to local historians or even drumpf according to family history by gwenda blair but by the time friedrich was born they had settled on trump germany did not yet exist as nation kallstadt was part of the province of palatinate in the bavarian kingdom the region was going though rough times unemployment was high those who had the courage left friedrich father died when he was eight years old and his mother struggled to make ends meet at years old friedrich decided to follow his sister katharina who had emigrated to the united states two years earlier he arrived in new york on board the eider on october he entered the through official channels but he had left bavaria illegally both he and his mother must have known that he would not have been granted official permission to leave the country unless he had paid bail guaranteeing that he would later return to do his mandatory military service said roland paul the recently retired director of the institute for palatinate regional history and folklife studies in the city of kaiserslautern according to documents uncovered by paul friedrich was stripped of his bavarian citizenship as his own request four years after arriving in the but friedrich was not done with palatinate seven years after his citizenship was withdrawn he visited the land of his birth to attend the wedding of his sister according to the family history by blair five years after that he returned once more to kallstadt where he met year old elisabeth christ they were engaged and friedrich came back third time to marry her in august but while the couple moved back to new york soon after the marriage and had daughter friedrich had promised his wife that he would sell his property in the and return to the land of their birth my grandmother said will marry you but will not go back to america with you donald trump american born cousin john walter told german filmmaker simone wendel in friedrich seemed intent on keeping his promise in he applied for permission to travel to kallstadt and although he claimed in his application that he intended to return to the united states within year with the purpose of residing and performing the duties of citizenship therein he took all his savings from the with him according to blair family history back in kallstadt friedrich attempted to get his citizenship back but though he secured the support of local authorities the district government put halt to his plans on february deportation notice was sent to the town office of kallstadt declaring that friedrich was to be told he has to leave bavarian state territory by may of this year at the latest friedrich was able to obtain three month grace period because his daughter had fallen ill but eventually he and his wife pregnant once more had no choice but to board the ship pennsylvania on july and return to new york shortly after that donald father fred trump junior was born the authorities said you are not german citizen you gave up your citizenship you have to leave says walter so they left and they went back to america and that why donald and are here friedrich now named frederick died in may of the spanish flu his widow survived her first husband by years and visited kallstadt many times during her life in february simone wendel the german filmmaker from kallstadt was given an audience with donald trump roughly two years earlier she had begun work on kings of kallstadt documentary about the two most famous sons of her tiny hometown donald trump and henry john heinz the inventor of heinz ketchup for months wendel had tried to arrange meeting with trump but his office had not replied to her letters she was only able to secure visit with the help of walter trump cousin who had visited kallstadt and seemed happy with the attention she was paying to the family history on the day of her visit wendel stood nervously next to walter in conference room on one of trump tower top floors she had brought linzer torte and two bottles of wine with screw on tops her plan was to sit down with walter and trump for coffee and cake the traditional afternoon snack in her home region but when she asked trump staff to make some coffee the only reaction she got was irritated faces his assistant just couldn be bothered she says hello john trump said when he entered the room shaking his cousin hand and looking confused at wendel in her loose turtle neck and the lonely cake on the huge table in front of her trump sat down in front of one meter long model of his boeing airliner and panoramic window overlooking new york central park wendel trying to remedy the situation pushed the cake in his direction and asked him to smell it afterwards just kept on thinking what on earth did do she says the cake looks really good trump said and he and wendel ended up talking for almost an hour until trump still claimed his family was swedish version of his family history first introduced by his father in reaction to the anti german sentiment in the during the two world wars but by the time wendel visited he had become proud of his german roots they grow them well in kallstadt he told her during their meeting they grow them very well believe me it good stock wow it beautiful trump said when she handed him picture of the house where his grandfather was born an inconspicuous one story building with gable roof that fantastic see how well maintained it is everything is perfectly maintained it great when their interview was over walter took wendel on tour of trump tower on one of the floors they ran into trump son eric trump have you ever heard the word kallstadt wendel asked him kallstadt worked incredibly well and you have to be proactive and you know you really help people sort of change their mind automatically he added new york city was incredible the way that worked so think that could be one step you could do the law enforcement policy in which police officers stop and question pedestrians regardless of whether they believe crime has been committed then search the pedestrians goals both clinton and trump met with egyptian president abdel fattah el sisi monday as the grueling presidential contest enters its final weeks clinton who served for four years as president barack obama secretary of state also met with japanese prime minister shinzo abe and ukrainian president petro poroshenko while the stakes are high for both candidates there is likely more on the line for trump who as foreign policy novice is still looking to prove his chops before the first presidential debate next monday trump used the meetings to try to convince voters that despite his often explosive personality he is qualified to serve as commander in chief the key for the blunt businessman is the visuals of the meeting hoping that voters see president as they observe him with world leader will say that with all the folks being in new york ve had lot of calls from lot of different people on the basis that doing well and you know they seem to think it important to maybe meet trump said monday on fox news don want to comment specifically on who but couple of people are coming over he later said ve already met with couple but refused to say which ones clinton used the meetings the rise of china with japan abe while clinton addressing the need for more vibrant and free civil society with egypt while she met with sisi while reporters were in the room clinton told sisi that she looked forward to talking about the path we are taking in order to build up new civil society new modern country that upholds the rule of law that respects human rights and liberties trump also meeting that mexico would not pay for it clinton campaign seized on the public back and forth between the mexican leader and trump with the democratic nominee calling it trump embarrassing international incident when you see that he can even go to foreign country without getting into public feud with the president think the answer is clear donald trump does not have the temperament to be our commander in chief clinton told voters in ohio after the meeting for her part clinton has decided to forgo the standard foreign tour as candidate because her aides feel she doesn need to burnish her foreign policy credentials instead she ll take the opportunity afforded in her home state to hobnob with foreign heavyweights and try to score political points clinton meeting with poroshenko in the eyes of her aides attempted to highlight the differences between the democratic and republican nominee on policy toward moscow clinton campaign and other democrats have accused trump armed forces but has fallen short of lethal assistance as some republicans have championed the official did not say however whether clinton would move toward lethal aid but said that she would take look at any requests from the ukrainians clinton meeting with sisi will make waves in the middle east because of the recent estrangement between the egyptian president government and the obama administration clinton according to an aide in the room emphasized the importance of respect for rule of law and human rights to egypt future progress and discussed ways to deepen cooperation particularly in the fight against isis clinton also used the meeting to call for the release of us citizen aya hijazi who has been imprisoned in egypt since after operating non profit in the country of us relations with egypt nation that is pivotal to the balance of power in the middle east is facing its own terror threats and would be critical to any renewed effort at israeli palestinian peace ve seen from trump and pro trump forces in fact pennsylvania is the state with the third highest number of ad dollars spent this cycle behind only florida and ohio clinton and trump will surely
